channel.title: Selection Sort
channel.description: Selection Sorts are when the computer looks for the highest number in a group of numbers and puts it at the bottom. Selection sorts are extremely slow compared to the more newer sorts out there. But how would you go about creating a selection sort?

item.title: Selection Sort
item.dc:creator: @Fat_Cookies Fat Cookies
item.description:
@Fat_Cookies wrote:

Although it’s totally possible for a selection sort to place the ordered elements at the bottom of the list, I’ve always found it conceptually easier to put it at the top.

The core of the algorithm works like:

input array[]
int sorted_index = -1 ;
while not_sorted {
    sorted_index = sorted_index + 1
    int high = 0
    for(sortedindex to length_of_list) {
        if array[sortedindex] > array[high] {
            high = sortedindex
        }
        high = high + 1
    }
    swap(array[sortedindex], array[high])
}

Don’t count 100% on that for validity but the most important thing is every time you’ve found the largest number you swap it with the “end” of the sorted list. You then make sure you’re only looking at elements after the sorted part.
